Award.AwardTitle: Digitization TCN: Collaborative: Documenting Fossil Marine Invertebrate Communities of the Eastern Pacific - Faunal Responses to Environmental Change over the last 66 million years
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fossils provide our only direct evidence of past biodiversity and how individual organisms to ecosystems have responded to past and long-term environmental change. This project fills a major gap in the documentation of past environmental change, making available digitized data from the especially rich fossil record of the eastern Pacific marine invertebrate communities of the Cenozoic, the 66 million years that have passed since the extinction of the dinosaurs. Digitization and integration of these data will foster increased accessibility, efficient analysis to understand past change, the identification of factors involved in that change, and enable predictions for how current biodiversity may be impacted by future change. Development of virtual fieldwork experiences will assist stakeholders and educators in understanding how field data and fossil collections are used to infer past ecosystem and environmental conditions.

The data currently exist as a vast collection of fossil specimens and printed materials distributed among multiple natural history collections: this project involves 7 primary institutions, one small collection and one federal institution and will integrate this digitized specimen data with the other two ongoing fossil networks through the web portal iDigPaleo, expanding the resource for fossil invertebrate information by spanning over 500 million years. This wealth of data will provide resources not only to researchers, but will be made available to K-16 educators, government, industry, and the general public. Through the national resource (iDigBio) these data will be integrated with information on modern organisms providing the means to understand important questions on niches, environmental change, transitions in sea levels, etc. Additionally, undergraduate and graduate students will be trained in the modern uses of natural history collections. This award is made as part of the National Resource for Digitization of Biological Collections through the Advancing Digitization of Biological Collections program and all data resulting from this award will be available through the national resource (iDigBio.org).

Institution.Name: Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History Foundation
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: LOS ANGELES COUNTY MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY FOUNDATION

Performance_Institution.Name: Los Angeles County Museum of Natural History Foundation

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Eastern Pacific Invertebrate Communities of the Cenozoic (EPICC) TCN project focused on making available more than 1.6 million fossil marine invertebrate specimens (snails, clams, crabs, corals, sea urchins, etc.) and their associated data from the Cenozoic (66 millions years ago (Paleocene) to the Pleistocene), from ten U.S. natural history collections. Although these fossil collections are vast (numbering in the millions of specimens), much of their specimen data are/were not in a digital format that was available online, which compromised the ability of large-scale paleobiology research and stymied access to collections data to off-site researchers. The goal of this TCN was, therefore, to digitize a large component of largely North American Eastern Pacific invertebrate paleontological data, creating exceptional research opportunities over geographic space and geologic time. Specifically, digitization of such fossil invertebrate specimen records allows unprecedented access to paleontological data for students, teachers, scholars, and other researchers for studies of paleoecology, paleobiodiversity, paleogeography, and extinction over a significant geological (deep) time.

The Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County's (NHMLA) invertebrate paleontology collection was the largest of the EPICC TCN collections and through NSF funding accomplished the following: 1) digitized over 1,065,501 invertebrate fossil specimen records many from southern California localities (in excess of its ~800,000 specimen goal), including more than 1,000 type specimens, all of which are currently (or imminently) available on iDigBio and GBIF; 2) photographed 10,062 specimen lots and individual specimens representing ~2,200 invertebrate fossil species; 3) geo-referenced 10,685 discrete fossil collection localities; 4) completed a drawer-level inventory of NHMLA invertebrate paleontology collections allowing a more accurate estimate of the collections specimen-count from 4 million specimens to 7 million specimens, with more than 5 million specimens directly pertinent to the EPICC-TCN; 5) developed a standardized taxonomy for Cenozoic mollusks (e.g. snails, clams, scallops, chitons, scaphopods) of the temperate Eastern Pacific (California to Washington) with 2,900 valid species names, which was shared with all EPICC TCN partnering institutions; 6) Entered 1300 species of the EPICC-TCN's standardized taxonomy into the Paleobiology Database (https://paleobiodb.org/#/) to the reduce misclassification by biodiversity aggregators such as GBIF and iDigBio; 7) hired and trained two Assistant Collections Managers in Invertebrate Paleontology at NHMLA; 8) mentored and trained 15+ undergraduate students (largely from local minority-serving community and 4-year colleges and universities), volunteers, and interns who learned techniques and best practices in invertebrate fossil specimen collection, preparation, identification, housing, photography, digitization, and georeferencing; 9) helped prepare 6 students who participated in original research based on EPICC TCN- digitized collections present research results at academic conferences (e.g. Geological Society of America and the Western Society of Malacologists); 10) trained 11 K-12 teachers to develop education and outreach activities and products associated with the EPICC-TCN in a STEM master teacher fellows program at California State University, Dominguez Hills; 11) communicated the data accessibility of NHMLA invertebrate fossil specimens as a result of the EPICC-TCN at academic/professional meetings (e.g. Geological Society of America (2016, 2017, 2018), North American Paleontological Convention (2019), Society of the Preservation of Natural History Collections (2017, 2018), iDigBio Biodiversity Data Meeting (2019), Western Society of Malacologists (2017, 2018), Southern California Unified Malacologists (2016, 2017, 2019, 2020), Biodiversity Heritage Library (2018)); 12) featured the EPICC-TCN project at NHMLA and other museum events reaching ~29,000 museum visitors (e.g. Women in Paleontology day and Fossil Fest 2019 & 2020 at the Raymond M. Alf Museum, NHMLA's Scavenger Safari 2018?2020, NHMLA's Nature Fest 2016?2019); 13) produced two peer-reviewed journal articles (e.g. Vendetti and Garland, 2020 & Marshall et al., 2018); 14) produced 16 conference abstracts for talk or poster presentations; 15) produced an identification guide for local, southern California Pleistocene fossils, which has been used as a resource for outreach events and education exercises (http://research.nhm.org/ip/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Knoll-Hill-Pleistocene1.jpg); 16) produced an image gallery of NHMLA fossils (https://www.flickr.com/photos/lacmip) and handbook for using the collections digitization software Emu (https://lacmip.github.io/emu/) and a stratigraphic inventory (https://research.nhm.org/ip/inventory/); and 17) promoted the EPICC-TCN and NHMLA invertebrate fossils via social media (e.g. www.instagram.com/fossilsofla/, www.facebook.com/fossilsofla/, twitter.com/fossilsofLA).

 


Last Modified: 08/20/2020
Modified by: Jann E Vendetti

Alf Museum, NHMLA's Scavenger Safari 2018?2020, NHMLA's Nature Fest 2016?2019); 13) produced two peer-reviewed journal articles (e.g. Vendetti and Garland, 2020 & Marshall et al., 2018); 14) produced 16 conference abstracts for talk or poster presentations; 15) produced an identification guide for local, southern California Pleistocene fossils, which has been used as a resource for outreach events and education exercises (http://research.nhm.org/ip/wp-content/uploads/2015/01/Knoll-Hill-Pleistocene1.jpg); 16) produced an image gallery of NHMLA fossils (https://www.flickr.com/photos/lacmip) and handbook for using the collections digitization software Emu (https://lacmip.github.io/emu/) and a stratigraphic inventory (https://research.nhm.org/ip/inventory/); and 17) promoted the EPICC-TCN and NHMLA invertebrate fossils via social media (e.g. www.instagram.com/fossilsofla/, www.facebook.com/fossilsofla/, twitter.com/fossilsofLA).
